--- title: "Tibble" --- ::: {.cell} :::
![](../images/tibble.png){style="width:150px"}
## Overview A __tibble__ (`tbl`) is a reimagining of the __data.frame__ (`df`) object. They are described as __data.frames__ that are: - __Lazy__: They don't change variable names and partial matching does not work. - __Surly__: They complain more such as when a variable does not exist. One important note is that __tibbles__ don't have row names. Although __tibbles__ have advantages compared to __data.frames__ they are not always more suited to the task than __data.frames__. However, __tibbles__ are generally always preferred over __data.frames__ when using __tidyverse__ packages. [Tibble homepage](https://tibble.tidyverse.org/) ## Sections

The sections in this book are: - [Creating tibbles](/tibble/creating_tibbles.qmd): Creating __tibbles__ with code, data.frame coercion, and reading in from files. - [Structure](/tibble/structure.qmd): Demonstrates the sturcture/format of a __tibble__. - [Subsetting](/tibble/subsetting.qmd): Subsetting __tibbles__ and the difference between using `$` and `[]`. - [Printing or viewing](/tibble/printing.qmd): Unique features of viewing __tibbles__. - [Adding rows and columns](/tibble/add_rows_and_columns.qmd): How to add new rows/columns and bind tibbles together. ## Tibble example Below is an example of: - Creating a basic tibble - Printing the tibble ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} #Create a tibble tbl <- tibble::tibble(Day = c("Mon", "Tue", "Wed"), Hawks = c(3,7,2), Pigeons = c(52,21,61), Starlings = c(1,2,1)) #Print tibble tbl ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 3 Ã— 4 Day Hawks Pigeons Starlings 1 Mon 3 52 1 2 Tue 7 21 2 3 Wed 2 61 1 ``` ::: :::
